findings.title: Unprotected SELFDESTRUCT Instruction
findings.description: The SELFDESTRUCT instruction is used without any protection, which can lead to unintended contract destruction.

findings.title: Unprotected Ether Withdrawal
findings.description: The smart contract allows unauthorized withdrawal of ether.

findings.title: Unchecked Call Return Value
findings.description: The return value of a call is not checked.

findings.title: State Variable Default Visibility
findings.description: The default visibility of state variables is public, which can lead to unintended access and modification.

findings.title: Uninitialized Storage Pointer
findings.description: The storage pointer has not been initialized before it was used.

findings.title: Delegate call to Untrusted Callee
findings.description: A delegate call is made to an untrusted callee, which can lead to unauthorized access or manipulation of sensitive data.

findings.title: Authorization through tx.origin
findings.description: The authorization mechanism relies on tx.origin, which can be manipulated by attackers.

findings.title: Block values as a proxy for time
findings.description: Using block values (e.g., block.number or block.timestamp) as a proxy for time can be insecure and may lead to unintended behavior.

findings.title: Incorrect Constructor Name
findings.description: The constructor of a contract has an incorrect name which can lead to unexpected behavior.

findings.title: Weak Sources of Randomness from Chain Attributes
findings.description: Using chain attributes as a source of randomness can be insecure since they are publicly accessible and can be manipulated by an attacker.

findings.title: Missing Protection against Signature Replay Attacks
Write to Arbitrary Storage Location
findings.description: The smart contract allows writing to arbitrary storage locations, which can lead to unauthorized data modification and potential security risks.

findings.title: Arbitrary Jump with Function Type Variable
Right-To Left Override control character (U+202E)
findings.description: The Right-To-Left Override control character (U+202E) can be used to manipulate the visual representation of text, potentially leading to phishing attacks or other security issues.

findings.title: Presence of unused variables
findings.description: Unused variables are present in the contract.

findings.title: Hash Collisions with Multiple Variable Length Arguments
Message call with hardcoded gas amount
Unencrypted Private Data On-Chain
findings.description: Private data is stored unencrypted on-chain.
